Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Seismic faulting causes rocks to melt and capture earthquake parameters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Large magnitude earthquakes rattle the world. The MW 7.6 1999 Chi-Chi earthquake claimed thousands of lives and cost Taiwan billions of dollars. Taiwan's history of devastating earthquakes nominates this region as one of the world's most seismically active areas. The collisions of the Eurasian and Philippine plates, forms two subduction zones on the eastern side of Taiwan. The collision process causes immense stresses with consequences including devastating earthquakes. During an earthquake, rocks slip against one another causing crushing, grinding and melting forming a rock called a pseudotachylyte. To better understand earthquakes, pseudotachylytes will be collected and analyzed. A new pseudotachylyte locality was recently discovered along the Hoping River in Taiwan. These 4.1 M.y.o. pseudotachylytes hold information on the magnitude and how sliding occurred. Sampling at the Hoping River will yield pseudotachylyte for analysis by 3D model and magnetics at National Taiwan Normal University in collaboration with Dr. En-Chao Yeh.

The principal objectives of this study are to determine if the pseudotachylyte veins originate from single or multiple slip events, analyze and model vein geometry in 3-D (to infer the attitude of the fault plane), average vein thickness, magnitude of the slip event(s) and direction of slip(s). This requires high resolution mapping and the collection of oriented samples. A tomographic analysis requires images for building a 3D model. The width of a pseudotachylyte generation vein is broadly proportional to earthquake magnitude. The angle between injection veins and the generation vein primarily reflects the ratio between normal and shear stresses. Furthermore, measuring the magnetic minerals orientations in these pseudotachylytes can yield coseismic slip kinematics. Together these techniques will aid in assessing focal mechanism and magnitude of an ancient earthquake leading to a better understanding of Taiwan's present seismic risk. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAPSI: Seismic faulting causes rocks to melt and capture earthquake parameters

A distinct type of fault rock known as a pseudotachylyte, create windows to view ancient earthquakes that occurred kilometers beneath the earth’s surface.  Fault pseudotachylytes form by melting along the fault plane caused by mechanical friction between rocks at high slip velocities. Pseudotachylytes represent the interface between sliding rock and provide invaluable information on seismic rupture processes.

Classic seismic investigations measure radiated energy from earthquakes in the form of waves. These waves provide a venue to measure earthquake source parameters such as magnitude and direction of sliding. Since seismologists utilize seismographs to measure seismic waves, the data reflects a historic timescale. Paleoseismic studies yield information on pre-historic earthquakes through other geologic techniques such as offset geomorphic features or pseudotachylytes. A region’s earthquake occurrence history or seismicity, utilizes both historic and prehistoric earthquake source parameters. Distributions of strains and geometry for example, in different tectonic settings may create dissimilarity in various regions seismicity’s. Probabilistic earthquake prediction utilizes a regions seismicity to help mitigate societal risk.

This research studies the second locality in Taiwan that contains pseudotachylytes and compliments recent research findings at a fraction of the cost. This study reveals the first true microstructural evidence of a melt origin pseudotachylyte at the Hoping River. Therefore, this study of the Hoping River pseudotachylyte indicates the first true evidence of a high velocity earthquake at this locality. The pseudotachylytes studied for this project, demonstrate the direction, magnitude and sense of slip of a pre-historic earthquake. These pseudotachylytes represent a 6.4 Mo magnitude earthquake event. Pseudotachylytes and other earthquake rocks formed solely by crushing and grinding were collected at the Hoping River locality.

The Hoping River pseudotachylytes may also add to the tectonic history of Taiwan. The pseudotachylytes may represent earthquakes that result from the rapid uplift of Taiwan which occurs faster than the exhumation of the Alps. Taiwan’s rapid exhumation, high erosion rates, dense population and climate creates hazards such as earthquakes and landslides. This study aids to lay the ground for further study of the pseudotachylyte link between exhumation rates and mechanisms. The Hoping River pseudotachylyte enhances the assessment of seismic risk in Taiwan. This research has been presented to the scientific community and community outreach continues to be a priority.
